Award.AwardTitle: Arctic Observing Networks: Collaborative Research:ITEX AON - understanding the relationships between vegetation change, plant phenology, and ecosystem function in a warming Arctic
Award.AbstractNarration:
Arctic ecosystems are changing in response to arctic warming, which is proceeding more than twice as fast as the global average. The International Tundra Experiment (ITEX) was established in the early 1990s to understand the effects of warming and environmental variability on tundra vegetation properties and ecosystem function. The ITEX program has been extremely valuable for detection of changes in tundra plant and ecosystem responses to experimental warming and to background climate change across sites that span the major ecosystems of the Arctic. In 2007, the Alaskan and Greenland ITEX sites were combined into an Arctic Observatory Network (AON). The current ITEX AON project will continue to document and understand Arctic terrestrial vegetation change and its ecosystem consequences by maintaining the long-term datasets of the ITEX-AON. The warming experiment of ITEX-AON allows us to assign the cause for observed changes in response to warming instead of relying on simple correlations. This project provides urgently needed data on changes in vegetation and the importance of these changes for ecosystem services from a variety of Arctic ecosystems. This project will provide training for postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate students in the emerging fields of remote sensing, cybertechnology and big-data analysis. The project will include outreach activities through strong relationships with the CLEO Institute in Miami; the Grand Valley State University Regional Math and Science Center; and K-12 school systems in Miami, Anchorage, Grand Rapids and El Paso. All data from this project are and will be freely available at the NSF Arctic Data Center.

The core datasets of the proposed research include manual observations of phenology, vegetation structure and composition, and ecosystem function (carbon flux and nutrient cycling) on long-term ITEX control and experimental warming plots, repeat measurement of vegetation plots on the long-term 1 km2 vegetation grids, and a multifactor warming/moisture experiment in Greenland. In 2009, the sampling scheme was expanded to include a larger spatial component to amplify the value of the measurements collected. This expansion included the addition of phenocams, automated mobile sensor platforms, and medium-scale aerial imagery. The automated platforms measure a suite of vegetation surface properties with minimal effort across focal transects spanning strong moisture and microtopographic gradients at a near-daily frequency. These measurements capture the fine-scale changes in vegetation over the growing season that are missed by lower frequency manual measurements and provide a bridge between manual measurements and aerial imagery. Medium-scale aerial imagery, using Kite Aerial or Unmanned Aerial Vehicles, is acquired throughout the growing season for scaling of manual and automated measurements; satellite imagery is referenced to medium-scale aerial imagery to aid scaling of responses to the regional level. In the newest phase of AON ITEX, we are particularly focused on understanding the relationship between landscape subsidence as a result of permafrost thaw and vegetation structure and function because of the potential for significant positive feedbacks to climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Tundra Experiment (ITEX) was established in the early 1990s to understand the effects of warming and environmental variability on tundra vegetation properties and ecosystem function. In 2007, multiple sites in northern Alaska and in northern Greenland ITEX combined to form US-funded ITEX-Arctic Observatory Network (AON). This project sustained ITEX-AON field-based observations, innovated technologies and analytical works, catalyzed new collaborations, and supported synthesis efforts. Combined and with an Arctic System Science perspective, these efforts have focused on improving both our understanding of Arctic terrestrial vegetation change and its ecosystem consequences within the ITEX-AON, and capacities to more effectively conduct multiscale observations of change in the future. Specific objectives of this award were to:

1) Build on the power of the ITEX experiment by continuing to monitor the long-term changes in phenology, vegetation structure and composition, and their ecosystem consequences in response to experimental warming and background climate variability and change.

2) Establish vegetation sampling grids at each location to increase the spatial coverage and integrity of our measurements.

3) Install infrastructure for automated monitoring of plant phenology, vegetation structure, and ecosystem function across our sites situated along environmental gradients.

4) Scale up ITEX measurements using grid-based sampling methods and multiple remote sensing approaches.

 

Numerous novel findings and innovations were produced from this research. The following summarizes the most significant of these:

1) Using ground-based hyperspectral remote sensing, this study has shown that remotely sensed metrics of vegetation productivity varies inter-annually more so for Arctic coastal and wet tundra communities than inland and dry tundra plant communities respectively. This pattern appears to translate to satellite-derived measures of vegetation productivity. Analyses of almost a decade of repeat terrestrial LiDAR scans at multiple sites in northern Alaska has shown that surface subsidence is occurring in Arctic coastal landscapes. Although there appears to be substantial inter-annual variability, subsidence rates of up to 13mm/yr have been recorded. When coupled with time series thaw depth measurements, results suggest that seasonal thaw depth does not have a pronounced change but permafrost thaw is occurring and historic stores of carbon and other nutrients are being re-mobilized. Results also suggest that subsidence of Arctic coastal landscapes increases effective sea level rise for the region to rates that are considered to be high relative to rates recorded elsewhere globally.

2) This study has contributed to a number of collaborative and synthetic studies. Due to a shift in aquatic macrophyte species assemblages that comprise less than 6% of the landscape area and differ in their capacities to conduct methane to the atmosphere, peak growing season methane efflux is predicted to have increased by 60% over the past 40 years on the Barrow Peninsula. Another study suggests this change in species assemblages could be related to increased nutrient availability from permafrost thaw. Spatially extrapolated measurements from a half-Century long herbivore exclusion experiment suggests that land-atmosphere carbon exchange shifts from a sink to a source during peak growing season when small mammals are excluded. In a circumarctic synthesis exploring the linkages between plant traits, environmental factors, and environmental change, soil moisture showed a stronger relationship with plant traits than temperature and plant community height was more responsive to experimental warming than other plant traits.

3) New acquisition and workflows for surface elevation, orthomosaic construction, and metrics of vegetation productivity workflows were developed for drone-based photography and a US-patent on a new time-lapse camera was awarded. Software tools for managing and analyzing ground-based hyperspectral data were developed, and a technique for spectrally unmixing single pixel signatures to derive plant functional types was prototyped. Several works highlight the need for caution when interpreting shifts in remote sensed metrics of vegetation productivity, which can be impacted by a range of biophysical factors.

4) The extensive data collected by this project has been archived and made freely available at the NSF Arctic Data Center, the Arctic Vegetation Archive, and the Ecological Spectral Information System. The scientific and technical findings outlined above have been published in peer-reviewed journals, a doctoral dissertation, and/or have been presented at internationally recognized conferences.

5) Beyond the intellectual merit outlined above, this project has had multiple broader impacts. We have delivered invited talks and conducted a range of hands on activities for community and K-12 community science outreach events in Utqiagvik, hosted a PolarTrec teacher who is developing bilingual (English/Spanish) lesson plans from her experience, and have participated in numerous other public speaking events. This award has partially supported a postdoc, two technicians, five graduate students, and two undergraduates. Personnel have received field and other professional training and have been involved in all aspects of the project. This award has also sustained some of the oldest sustained environmental observations of their kind in the Arctic and facilitated the active participation of US researchers in several international syntheses and scientific planning efforts.
